conclusion: To find the radius r_max of a drop just before it separates from the nozzle, consider the forces acting on the droplet.
The droplet separates when the gravitational force overcomes the surface tension force.
The gravitational force acting on the droplet is F_gravity = (4/3) π r^3 ρ g.
ρ is the density of water, g is the acceleration due to gravity, r is the radius of the droplet.
The surface tension force is F_surface tension = σ 2 π r.
σ is the surface tension of water, r is the radius of the droplet.
The droplet separates when the gravitational force equals the surface tension force: (4/3) π r^3 ρ g = σ 2 π r.
Cancel out common terms (π and r) to simplify the equation: (4/3) r^2 ρ g = 2 σ.
Rearrange the equation to solve for r: r^2 = (3 σ)/(2 ρ g).
Solve for r: r = sqrt((3 σ)/(2 ρ g)).
The radius r_max of a drop just before it separates from the nozzle is r_max = sqrt((3 σ)/(2 ρ g)).
